text: As in the case of bacteriophage batch culture, we can define an eclipse period, a latent period before appearance of the first progeny virions in the culture fluid, and a rise period.
In tissue culture, the time course of animal virus replication is usually much longer (hours or days) than that of bacteriophages (typically less than an hour under optimal conditions).
Tissue-culture methods have provided virologists with a simple in vitro method for testing a multitude of chemical and antibiotic agents.
The burst size of animal viruses, however, is typically several orders of magnitude larger than that of phages.
The fluid bathing the tissue layer is sampled for virus concentration.
At 8 hours, infected cells have detached from the culture dish.
The reason for the larger burst size is probably that the volume of a host cell is much larger than that of a bacterial host, thus providing a larger supply of materials to build virions.
By 24 hours, cells have lysed or in some cases clumped with other cells.
The cells must be immortalized—that is, genetically altered—to continue cell division indefinitely.
Since then, tissue culture has remained the most effective way to study the molecular biology of animal and plant viruses and to develop vaccines and antiviral agents.
Some viruses can be grown in a tissue culture of cells growing confluently on a surface.
What kinds of questions about viruses can be addressed in tissue culture, and what questions require infection of an animal model?

Under what conditions does the growth of cellular microbes give rise to a step curve?
Could you design an experiment in which viruses generate an exponential curve?
